description: From Middle English lust, from Old English lust (â€œlust, pleasure, longingâ€), from Proto-Germanic *lustuz. Akin to Old Saxon, Dutch lust, Old Frisian, Old High German, German Lust, Swedish lust, Danish lyst, Icelandic lyst, Old Norse losti, Gothic ğŒ»ğŒ¿ğƒğ„ğŒ¿ğƒ (lustus), and perhaps to Sanskrit à¤²à¤·à¥ (laá¹£), à¤²à¤·à¤¤à¤¿ (laá¹£ati, â€œto desireâ€) and Albanian lushÃ« (â€œbitch, savage dog, promiscuous womanâ€), or to English loose. Compare list (â€œto pleaseâ€), listless.

entries.meaning: A feeling of strong desire, especially such a feeling driven by sexual arousal.
examples: Seeing Leslie fills me with a passionate lust.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A general want or longing, not necessarily sexual.
examples: The boarders hide their lust to go home.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A delightful cause of joy, pleasure.
examples: An ideal son is his father's lasting lust.

verbs.description: lust (third-person singular simple present lusts, present participle lusting, simple past and past participle lusted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, usually in the phrase "lust after") To look at or watch with a strong desire, especially of a sexual nature.
examples: He was lusting after the woman in the tight leather miniskirt.
